I am recovering from the death of my 'loved one', Joe, the love of my life.  (He opted for the California option to end one's life in the face of terminal illness.  On the morning of September 1st, 2020, he woke up and said, 'It's time.)  I played this song not knowing it was a memorial-song.  Bravo!  This song, these words, this melody, and performance, were excellently executed.  This is art; ART...capturing life, in all it's beauty, and tragedy, that tragedy that is the loss of our loved ones; when they 'leave' this world-our world; when they are 'taken from us' by someone-thing greater than ourselves, for some unknown (to us), greater reason or plan.  -Max-photographer/writer,  Palm Springs Resort Cities-92234 (Cradle of COACHELLA Music Festival)  Joe, I love you and miss you.  I believe you are here, by my side, especially when I am sad and lonely.

My God. Every word of this song pierces me like a dagger. I think everyone has one chance to find the person they were meant to be with and when you lose them...it shatters you to the core, turning your heart to dust. I live this sadness every day.

It will get better, man. It might seem like it shattered you, but it only shook you really hard. One day in near future you will go to bed and realize that this day was the first one where you felt a tiny bit better again. And the next day will be the same. And the next one. There will be setbacks as well, but overall you will recover. And I agree that there are people like no others. But there are more than one on this planet. You will find a second one and once you found her/him, you will realize that itâ€™s even better now than with the first person, because every single day of these bad past times, brought you exactly to where you are then. Where you belong and where you were meant to be. Keep your head up, allow yourself to be happy and stay positive in your head! Itâ€™s gonna be fine.

Lifeâ€¦ the sun comes up and the world continues. What is important is the impact you have while your are here. God gives and takes all at the same time. Stay strong and see it through. Things really do get better â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹

My grandpa passed away from Covid two months ago last week and today is his birthday. It took him three days between being diagnosed, going to the hospital and passing away. I thought about all of the times the idea of losing him haunted me and I never ever imagine he would be go this way. He was the most loving person I've ever met, and the most important person in my life. He was there for me every step of the way and he accepted me when I came out like it was nothing. I haven't seen him for four years prior his passing because I had moved to LA from Brazil to try to pursue my dreams, and though he understood, he once said he was afraid he would never see me again. Til this day, it's one of my biggest regrets. I'm sorry I didn't make it back in time, grandpa. I'm sorry I didn't conquer my dreams on time. I still choke on my words when I try to sing or write about him, nothing I ever write seems to be accurate to my feelings. This song was it. It described everything I've been feeling since he passed. When this song came out, I tried not to listen to it because I knew it was about Alisha and it was about grief. Dan, his family and the boys have gone through so much these past years that I knew this album would hit harder than "Origins". Thank you Imagine Dragons for being everything that you are. Yeah, I'm a wreck since you've been gone. Happy birthday, grandpa. I miss you.

Sometimes people No matter how strong or how fuffiled in life can never come back from a death if a loved one or best friend. Its hard to live in a world when you have lost that one person grounding you to life and sometimes in the end they cant handle it. The pain is too much. When you bottle up that pain instead of letting the world know things can get worse. This song is like a tribute for those people who cant ever let their emotions show in fear if looking weak. Pain strikes hard and hopefully so can letting someone in. I hear so many songs like this and in the end i cry because i know pain of losing someone you care about i feel alone. I cry every time I hear it. It beautifully captures life after the loss of someone you love so deeply. It's been 7 years since I lost my husband. He had just turned 39, and his heart simply stopped beating. No illness, no medical conditions, no drugs, no reason.  My heart hasn't beat properly since that day. I lost my dad 11 months and 1 week later when his heart stopped. 6 months and 3 days after I lost my dad (on my birthday) I had pit tickets to see Imagine Dragons, and got off work early to get ready, when I received the phone call that my best friend was found after committing suicide. I still can't bring myself to go to one of their shows. Maybe next year.

ğŸ’™

@@franco7091 yes. The photo of the girl at the end of this video was Dan Reynold's sister-in-law, and a high school friend of mine. She graduated from Stirling High School in Alberta Canada before marrying Paul Reynolds (who she met at college) and moving to Reynolds home town of Las Vegas. She was our Class President. I served with her as Vice President. We had just planned our High School Reunion together when she learned of her cancer diagnosis.
@@rachelrasmussen1101 That's amazing. It's pretty clear Dan loved her a ton. This is one of the most beautiful and sad songs they've ever written. I'm sure she would have loved it.
@@rachelrasmussen1101 Funny how we sometimes think of celebrities as not being regular people.  Beautiful song, tragic circumstances that brought it about

@@blinddogroofer I'm ashamed of myself for how true that is. I went to the funeral, eager to mourn with Alisha's family, (her parents and siblings that I had known well in High School), but it wasn't until I was pulling into the parking lot that it even occurred to me "is Dan Reynolds going to be here?" Of course he was, and I got to visit with his wife at the luncheon (she had written a beautiful poem for Alisha). But while we (my high school friends and I) hugged and cried with all her family, we sat just a little shy of Dan and his celebrity, unsure of how to share grief with him. When I see him standing in the rain in this video, all the people with umbrellas abandoning him, I wonder if there was something more I could have done.
@@rachelrasmussen1101 Don't be too hard on yourself.  No one knows what to do all of the time.  I bet people "from before" are very valuable and in short supply.
@@blinddogroofer thank you for that.

Alisha Reynolds, Dan's Sister-in-law died from Cancer, on a interview he say she was a light in the darkness, bringing joy everywhere she goes and every person she cross by, in my personal experiences I have lost 3 love ones against Cancer, leaving a void in my heart, first was one of my paternal uncles, second my elder brother and third my maternal uncle, others died from either Parkinson (Paternal Uncle), Covid-19 (My grandmother) and a rare illness (Another paternal uncle), this was one by one on a short lapse of time, leaving me with no chance of mourn those lost!! so I feel sorry for Dan, Cancer is a hell of a Sickness!!! I lost my grandma this year due to complications from Dementia. She was in Europe and I couldn't visit her at the end. In the summer of 2020 I had plans to fly over to visit, but the pandemic tossed that trip out the window. I regret so much not being able to see her one last time, despite knowing full well that she wouldn't recognize me. It pains me knowing I won't see her again. I won't see that beautiful smile and hear that contagious laugh of hers. I won't sit down in the kitchen with tea and talk to her, and I won't see her carefully watering and caring for each flower in her garden...To say this song hit too close to home is an understatement. Time passes and it does become easier. But sometimes I will remember something and it all comes crashing in again. Imagine Dragons really captured the emotions perfectly with this song.  Thank you for this masterpiece. It let me get some of my grief out. It never truly goes away.

Alright, here it goes. I'm old. Which means I've survived (so far) and a lot of people I've known and loved, did not. I've lost friends, best friends, acquaintances, co-workers, grandparents, mom, relatives, pets teachers, mentors, students, neighbors, and a host of other folks. I have no children, and I can't imagine the pain it must be to lose a child. But here's my two cents. I wish I could say you get used to people dying. I never did. I don't want to. It tears a hole through me whenever somebody I love dies, no matter the circumstances. But I don't want it to "not matter". I don't want it to be something that just passes. My scars are a testament to the love and the relationship that I had for and with that person. And if the scar is deep, so was the love. So be it. Scars are a testament to life. Scars are a testament that I can love deeply and live deeply and be cut, or even gouged, and that I can heal and continue to live and continue to love. And the scar tissue is stronger than the original flesh ever was. Scars are a testament to life. Scars are only ugly to people who can't see. As for grief, you'll find it comes in waves. When the ship is first wrecked, you're drowning, with wreckage all around you. Everything floating around you reminds you of the beauty and the magnificence of the ship that was, and is no more. And all you can do is float. You find some piece of the wreckage and you hang on for a while. Maybe it's some physical thing. Maybe it's a happy memory or a photograph. Maybe it's a person who is also floating. For a while, all you can do is float. Stay alive. In the beginning, the waves are 100 feet tall and crash over you without mercy. They come 10 seconds apart and don't even give you time to catch your breath. All you can do is hang on and float. After a while, maybe weeks, maybe months, you'll find the waves are still 100 feet tall, but they come further apart. When they come, they still crash all over you and wipe you out. But in between, you can breathe, you can function. You never know what's going to trigger the grief. It might be a song, a picture, a street intersection, the smell of a cup of coffee. It can be just about anything...and the wave comes crashing. But in between waves, there is life.  Somewhere down the line, and it's different for everybody, you find that the waves are only 80 feet tall. Or 50 feet tall. And while they still come, they come further apart. You can see them coming. An anniversary, a birthday, or Christmas, or landing at O'Hare. You can see it coming, for the most part, and prepare yourself. And when it washes over you, you know that somehow you will, again, come out the other side. Soaking wet, sputtering, still hanging on to some tiny piece of the wreckage, but you'll come out.  Take it from an old guy. The waves never stop coming, and somehow you don't really want them to. But you learn that you'll survive them. And other waves will come. And you'll survive them too. If you're lucky, you'll have lots of scars from lots of loves. And lots of shipwrecks. (GSnow)

This song is so beautiful. And like most of their lyrics, I related to the notion of 'being wrecked', whether or not you have a trauma in your life. I am still mourning my father's passing, and for some reason, any emotional stressor that come my way, is just amplified by the unprocessed mourning. This song is beautiful, so beautiful that I don't know if I can listen to it all the time because it reminds me too much of the valley I've been in for the last three years. That being said, just months after my father's passing, I finally caught a break seeing Imagine Dragons life, so thank you for letting me enjoy the present for a bit. I am super-excited for what comes next.

Alisha Dawn Reynolds, age 38, passed away April 7, 2019 in Houston, TX after a 9 month battle with lymphoma. She was born on May 7, 1980 at Fort Lewis, WA to Mark and Brenda Durtschi and grew up in Washington, Virginia, Germany, and Canada. Alisha was married to Paul Quayle Reynolds on August 23, 2003, and the two of them lived in Nashville and then Las Vegas with their seven beautiful kids. She is survived by her parents Mark and Brenda Durtschi, her brother Jared Durtschi, her sister Heidi Sitake, her husband Paul Reynolds, and her children Axel, Margaret, Louisa, Boone, Henry, Edith, and Raedwulf.
